rename.from: Unable to see mlflow ui at http://127.0.0.1:5000
rename.to: Unable to see mlflow ui at http://127.0.0.1:5000 on macOS Sierra version 10.12.3

body:
Thanks for reporting this. A few questions about it:
- Are there any additional messages beyond "worker timeout"? Maybe on stderr or stdout?
- Do you have a `mlruns` directory in the location where you ran `mlflow ui`? If so, are any runs created using an older version of MLflow? (This isn't expected to be a problem but would be good to know.)
- What exact path is MLflow installed in? Try doing `which mlflow`, and also make sure it's the one that came from `pip3` and not some other installation.

Just to be clear, you don't need `npm` to run `mlflow ui`; we only use it for building the client-side JavaScript files needed for MLflow, but we don't use it as a server. It should just require that one Python process on port 5000 + child processes to serve requests, but it seems that those are crashing for you.

Out of curiosity, by any chance will `http://localhost:5000`work even though `http://127.0.0.1:5000` will not?   I currently am able to repro this (both issues) with the following configuration:
* OS Platform: `macOS High Sierra 10.13.2`
* MLflow Install: `pip install mlflow`
* MLflow version: `0.2.1`
* Python version:  `Python 3.6.5 :: Anaconda, Inc.`
* npm vresion: `not installed`

This *may* be a macOS specific issue as per [Gunicorn 19.7.0 raises Socket Error! #1487](https://github.com/benoitc/gunicorn/issues/1487).  Once I had reconfigured my **TCP/IP > Configure IPv6** from *Automatically* (default) to *Link-local only* then I was able to connect to `http://127.0.0.1:5000'.
OK, maybe we should just document this then unless there is a workaround to the Gunicorn thing. It's too bad that the logs print out 127.0.0.1 but we can at least warn about this issue.

I have similar issue. When I first cloned the repository and followed the tutorial by passing train alpha and l1 all worked. I started the UI at the directory having mlruns and it did work in the browser but then after exploring the interface and few refreshes here and there, it suddenly went down without warning at the terminal, while the same terminal shows it as running normally. I took it down, restarted computer and started mlflow ui again and at the browser was getting NOT FOUND. No clue what the issue is now.

btw @dennyglee I did what you suggested to change **TCP/IP > Configure IPv6** from _Automatically_ (default) to _Link-local only_ and it did not solve the problem. Any clue? My terminal logs is similar to the OP as well as the operating system. 

**EDIT:** I tried running the same on Ubuntu 16.04 in virtualbox and got the same result. Not working at all. Is there any dependency that might have been updated and messed up the library? Also, I am running these with virtualenv environments in both macOS and Ubuntu.
Hi @stenpiren - to confirm you're running Ubuntu 16.04 in Virtualbox on macOS?  If so - which version of the OS?  Thanks!
hi @dennyglee . it's Ubuntu 16.04.4 LTS. Basically, I tried both: running on macOS alone, then tried in Ubuntu in Virtualbox. Both cases got the page not found.

@stenpiren did you happen to run the `mlflow ui` from the root path of your cloned repo, for example,  from the $HOME/mlflow which is your project path?

Similar error happened to me and I finally figured out what caused it. Python searches the module by sys.path and the current directory is the first path it searches. The mlflow project directory structure has `mlflow/mlflow/server` in it. So when the `gunicorn` tries to run the app, it is not getting from the installed one. Instead, it is looking at the cloned project. And because the js/build does not exist (aka server is not built) yet, the worker fails.

Same problem, I followed the tutorial and got 404 error, changing directory to `examples` folder solved the problem. 

I think you just have to update the documentation for the tutorial. Cloning the whole source code of `mlflow` isn't necessary. Just do `pip install mlflow --user` as a requirement instead.

Thank you for this amazing package.

@stenpiren I had the same problem, which was due to the fact that the web files (js, css) were not built. I did the following in a virtualenv environment:
 - build the UI and wheel files, following this section: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst#building-a-distributable-artifact
 - install mlflow within the virtualenv environment: `pip install -e .`

Then you can run `mlflow ui` using the latest source version.

Had the same issue but moving to the examples folder as described by @mycaule worked for me!

One thing to note though. When I started the UI in the examples directory, if running locally, it looks for runs in the examples/mlruns directory. So as a quick hack, I added a symlink with `ln -s ../mlruns ./mlruns`, run from the examples directory.

Creating the symlink like @tszumowski pointed out caused other issues when trying to view the UI. In the context of following the tutorial, I think @mycaule meant:

1. Change into the `example` folder in the first place to run the the `train.py` with varying parameters (vs running it from the root folder of the repo) - `mlflow` creats the `mlruns` folder in the working directory that the script was invoked from (in this case `<project_root>/example`
2. Run `mlflow ui` from the same `<project_root>/example` folder, and it will now successfully load the mlflow runs in `<project_root>/example/mlruns`

At least that's what worked for me
